div.p: Dear D205 Families,

Thank you for your support and involvement as parents in the District 205 remote e-learning process during this time. Todays Remote Professional Learning Day provided strong opportunities for our faculty and staff to collaborate and continuously improve our academic procedures and provide the necessary support and learning opportunities for our students.
The purpose of this communication is to provide additional specific information related to our evolving plans for remote e-learning, including:

li.p: Reminder of Attendance Procedures
Parent & Student Input on Remote E-Learning
Guidance for Parents on Feedback, Assignments, and Grades

div.p: As we continue to improve our approaches, notices and updates will be made available through the Find it Fast menus on each schools website.

p.strong: 1. Reminder of Attendance Procedures

div.p: For EC-5 Parents: Monday-Thursday, between 8-11 a.m. parents need to complete the Daily E-Learning Attendance Check-In for Parents EC-5. If a parent is unable to check-in a student, the student will be marked as an Unexcused Absence.

For 6-12 Students: Thank you for helping remind our students that on Monday-Thursday between 9-11 a.m., students in grades 6 to 12 must use their district-issued Chromebook, home computer, or mobile device to log into Google Classroom at https://classroom.google.com and follow the directions in the Daily E-Learning Attendance Directions for Students 6-12 to submit their attendance. If a student is unable to mark themselves present by 11 a.m., the student will be marked as an Unexcused Absence.

For All Parents: Similar to a typical school day, if a student is ill or unable to participate in the E-Learning Day, parents and guardians must call the school attendance line by 11:00am to report an absence from e-learning. NOTE: On Fridays, parents and students will not be required to log/call in for attendance, nor submit any learning evidence, as the days are designated for remote professional learning.

p.strong: 2. Parent & Student Input on Remote E-Learning
p.br: For EC-5 Parents: Thank you to over 700 parents and family members of students in grades EC-5 able to share survey feedback about their experiences so far with remote e-learning.

li.p: Whats going well: Our teachers and our families are working incredibly hard to support their students. Many parents thanked specific teachers for their responsiveness and care and 90 percent of students are getting feedback from teachers daily or every few days. The second week of e-learning has brought more specific and tailored assignments directly from teachers to help advance learning and parents report that as a positive development. A few parents even mentioned that despite the stress of trying to balance their own jobs, other children, and family needs, the opportunity to get to know their children as learners and become more familiar with their work was a welcome impact during this challenging time.

Where we can improve: Students miss their teachers, their friends, and their classmates. Providing more interactions (short and pre-scheduled) with students was a common suggestion for improvement. Another common suggestion was to clarify which course areas and assignments are priorities and which are optional. Finally, students have access to many tools and websites to learn from - but navigating all the links, logins, and notifications is a challenge.

div.p: For 6-12 Parents: Last week, about 2,900 students in grades 6-12 shared their experiences so far with remote e-learning.

li.p: Whats going well: Most students reported that e-learning is going fine. Eight-five percent of students are getting feedback daily or every few days from their teachers. Many students also mentioned an appreciation for the autonomy over their schedules and the flexibility to work at their own pace.

Where we can improve: Current guidance from the ISBE regarding the recommended length of sustained attention for students during remote e-learning suggests middle school students should spend a maximum of 3 hours per day and high school students up to 4 hours per day on schoolwork. But over forty percent of students report spending more time than this. For students feeling stress, having too much work was the most common source of that stress. Though most students report being able to do their work independently, many students also want more opportunities to connect with teachers online.

p.strong: Next Steps for District 205

li.p: The section that follows is intended to clarify expectations regarding assignments, feedback, and grades for parents - including information about which subject areas are optional extension opportunities, as well as the frequency of feedback and grades.
We will be working with our school leaders and technology department to discuss ways to simplify navigating online tools.

Teachers and administrators will use time during the upcoming remote planning Fridays to discuss how to continuously improve the balance of assignments for students as well as technology and other related opportunities for virtual interaction.

p.strong: 3. Guidance for Parents on Feedback, Assignments, and Grades
p.br: Teachers will continue to provide feedback on student work in key content and skill areas, including formative feedback aimed at improvement and feedback that indicates a students level of performance (grades or scores). Student learning and demonstrations of learning in a remote setting may look different than in-person work, and will require flexibility on the part of teachers and students.

div.p: As a reminder, guidance from the Illinois State Board of Education indicates that student grades prior to the transition to remote learning (as of 3/13/2020) can only be maintained or improved, provided the student demonstrates continued engagement and ability at a passing level after the transition to instructional remote learning day. In accordance with this guidance, D205 would like to share the following details for clarity and awareness.

p.strong: For EC-5 Parents & Students

li.p: Students in grades EC-5 are asked to send one (1) piece of evidence for literacy and one (1) piece for math per day of remote learning from any of the work done directly to their teacher - either by email or SeeSaw (Please reference the Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu Sample Template).
If unable to upload or send evidence of learning, parents are encouraged to contact the teacher or case manager.

Teachers will continue to provide feedback where appropriate. Similar to learning in the classroom, not every piece of evidence submitted by students will be used for grading; some will be used as formative information for teachers and students.
Teacher teams are working to identify at least one key assignment per week in English Language Arts and math that will be used for trimester 3 grading.

All activities for Specials in grades K-5 (Art, Music, PE, Media Specialists, and Spanish in Grades 3-5) are optional extension opportunities for students to complete. These extension opportunities will be updated each week by teachers to provide engagement and enrichment. Students may send evidence of learning to Specials Teachers if they choose for feedback; yet, they are intended to serve as optional extension experiences for students.

p.strong: For 6-8 Parents & Students

li.p: Teacher teams are working to identify key assignments each week to be graded. For courses that do not meet daily, such as Science and Social Studies, teacher teams are identifying at least one assignment to be graded every other week.
Letter grades will be provided to students in grades 6-8 at the end of the second semester.

The following courses in grades 6-8 are optional extension opportunities for students to complete. These extension opportunities will be updated each day by teachers to provide engagement and enrichment. Students may send evidence of learning to the teacher(s) if they choose for feedback; yet, they are intended to serve as optional extension experiences for students.
Band, Orchestra, Choir, World Language, Music, Art, PE/Health, Creative Tech, Industrial Tech, Family and Consumer Science, and Project Lead the Way.

p.strong: For 6-12 Parents & Students (How Grades are Calculated)

li.p: Teachers will continue to provide feedback where appropriate. Similar to learning in the classroom, not every piece of evidence submitted by students will be used for grading; some will be used as formative information for teachers and students.
A new term in the gradebook called C1 will reflect student grades up to 3/13/2020, which was the last day of in-school learning.
For most courses, assignments and grades added after 3/13/20 (during remote e-learning) will appear in a term for second semester called S2.
Students and parents will see C1 and S2 information in PowerSchool to help students and families understand how grades are improving.
Student grades CANNOT go down as a result of remote e-learning, so at the end of the semester, teachers will assign either the C1 or S2 grade, depending on whichever is higher.
For clarity, please note that a students temporary semester 2 grade (S2) may fluctuate - going down and up during remote e-learning, as shown in the figure that follows.

Yet, assignment grades cannot harm the students overall grade as it was on 3/13/2020. The assignment grades can only help improve the students overall grade, as illustrated in this example where the students grade was 88% on 3/13/2020 and then eventually 91% (at the future final semester 2 grade).

div.p: Should parents have questions, please reach out to our dedicated teachers. As we continue to adapt academically, I would like to again thank our learning community for their support in taking care of one another during this time, and for the ongoing focus on health and wellness together.

Sincerely,
Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent

hr.p: Estimadas Familias del Distrito Escolar 205,

Queremos expresar nuestro agradecimiento por su apoyo e involucramiento como padres de familia del Distrito escolar 205, dentro del proceso del aprendizaje remoto y a distancia que estamos viviendo en estos momentos. El da de hoy hicimos el primer Da de Aprendizaje Profesional Remoto para todo el Profesorado y Personal, con el mismo, hemos trado oportunidades a todo nuestro personal docente y administrativo para mejorar nuestros procedimientos acadmicos y brindar oportunidades de apoyo al aprendizaje para todos nuestros estudiantes.
El propsito de este comunicado es proveer informacin especfica relacionada con los planes que involucran el aprendizaje remoto o a distancia, incluyendo:

li.p: Recordatorio y Procedimientos de Asistencia Virtual Diaria
Opinin de los Padres y Estudiantes en el Aprendizaje Virtual y a Distancia
Gua para los Padres de acuerdo a a la Retroalimentacin,las Tareas y Calificaciones

hr.p: Al mismo tiempo que continuamos mejorando nuestros procedimientos, brindaremos la oportunidad de encontrar la informacin y actualizaciones en el rea de bsqueda de nuestra pgina web bajo la frase en ingls Find it Fast en el men principal.

p.strong: 1. Recordatorio y Procedimientos de Asistencia Virtual Diaria

hr.p: Para los Padres de Educacin Temprana hasta el Quinto Grado (EC- 5): De lunes a Jueves de 8:00-11:00 a.m. los padres de familias necesitan completar los pasos detallados en la siguiente conexin: Daily E-Learning Attendance Check-In for Parents EC-5. Si el padre de familia no tiene la oportunidad de checar la asistencia virtual de su hijo(a), el estudiante estar siendo marcado con una Ausencia Injustificada o U.

Para los Padres de Estudiantes de Sexto a Doceavo (6 - 12): Muchas gracias de antemano por recordarles a sus hijos que, de lunes a jueves entre 9:00-11:00 a.m. deben de poner su asistencia, ya sea con la computadora porttil, Chromebook que el Distrito les prest, o la computadora de la casa o cualquier dispositivo de tecnologa que tengan disponible para entrar a los salones virtuales de Google, mejor conocidos como Google Classroom en la conexin https://classroom.google.com y por favor, siga las instrucciones diarias que a continuacin detallamos, Daily E-Learning Attendance Directions for Students 6-12. Si el estudiante no puede marcar su asistencia virtual para las 11:00 am, el estudiante ser marcado con una Ausencia Injustificada o U.

Para Todos los Padres de Familia: De manera similar a un da tpico escolar, si el estudiante est enfermo o ausente para participar desde su casa en el da escolar de Aprendizaje Virtual, los padres de familia o tutores tiene que notificarnos antes de las 11:00 am a travs de la lnea telefnica de ausencias de su respectiva escuela school attendance line. Nota: Todos los viernes han sido destinados para aprendizaje profesional de los profesores, por lo tanto, no es requisito que los padres, ni estudiantes entren a los salones virtuales, ni que llamen por telfono.

p.strong: 2. Opinin de los Padres y Estudiantes en el Aprendizaje Virtual y a Distancia
Para los Padres de Educacin Temprana hasta el Quinto Grado (EC-5):

hr.p: Muchas gracias a los 700 padres de familia que han externado su opinin sobre la experiencia de aprendizaje virtual y a distancia en el sondeo de opinin que hicimos hace poco.

li.p: Lo que est funcionando: Nuestros profesores y familias estn trabajando arduamente para apoyar a los estudiantes. Ha habido muchos padres de familia que han agradecido directamente a algunos profesores por su respuesta y cuidado, y 90% de los estudiantes han tenido respuesta del profesorado de manera diaria o casi diaria. La segunda semana del aprendizaje virtual ha trado tareas y trabajos ms especficos moldeados a las necesidades de los estudiantes, que han sido elaborados para que los estudiantes avancen en su aprendizaje; los padres han reportado sto como algo positivo. Incluso algunos padres de familia expresaron que, a pesar del estrs de tratar de balancear sus trabajos en casa y otros nios, ms las necesidades familiares, han apreciado y se han dado cuenta de una manera positiva del proceso en el que sus hijos estn aprendiendo.

reas en las que podemos mejorar: Nos damos cuenta de que los estudiantes extraan a sus maestros, amigos y compaeros de clase. Una sugerencia que nos ha llegado fue la de promover y mejorar ms interaccin (corta o pre-organizada en el horario) con otros estudiantes. Otra sugerencia comn fue la de clarificar qu cursos, reas y tarea tienen prioridad y cules son opcionales. Finalmente y sabiendo que los estudiantes tiene acceso a muchas herramientas y pginas de internet, se nos ha notificado que ha sido un gran desafo navegar las conexiones, notificaciones y entrada a dichas pginas.

hr.p: Para los Padres de Estudiantes de Sexto a Doceavo (6 - 12): La semana pasada, 2900 estudiantes de entre los grados 6 y 12 compartieron su experiencia sobre el aprendizaje remoto,

li.p: Lo que est funcionando: La mayora de los estudiantes report que el aprendizaje virtual les est funcionando. 85 % de estudiantes est recibiendo respuesta de sus profesores de manera diaria o en un par de das. Muchos estudiantes mencionaron su aprecio a la nueva autonoma y flexibilidad de decidir sus propios horarios y de hacer sus tareas a su propio paso.

reas en las que podemos mejorar: La gua actual del Departamento de Educacin del Estado de Illinois, ISBE por sus siglas en ingls, recomienda que la duracin del aprendizaje remoto, es de 3 horas mximo diario para un estudiante de secundaria; y de 4 horas diarias para un estudiante de preparatoria, sin embargo ms de 40% de los estudiantes reportaron que estn pasando muchas ms horas en el aprendizaje remoto. Para los estudiantes, el estrs est directamente relacionado con la carga de trabajo acadmico, aunque la mayora report que han podido trabajar de manera independiente y quieren ms oportunidades de conectarse con sus profesores en lnea.

p.strong: Siguientes Pasos para el Distrito 205

li.p: La siguiente seccin tiene la intencin de clarificar a los padres de familia cules son las expectativas relacionadas con las tarea, la retroalimentacin y las calificaciones, incluyendo informacin acerca de qu materias o reas son opcionales y cules son aquellas con oportunidades de extensin de tiempo para entregar dichas tareas. As mismo incluimos la frecuencia de la retroalimentacin y las calificaciones.
Estamos trabajando con nuestros lderes escolares y con el Departamento de Tecnologa para discutir maneras de simplificar las herramientas de navegacin en lnea.

El profesorado y los administradores usarn todos los viernes para planeamiento y discusin de cmo mejorar y balancear nuestros procesos de tareas para todos los estudiantes, as mismo, como la tecnologa y otras oportunidades relacionadas con la interaccin virtual.

p.strong: 3. Gua para los Padres, Retroalimentacin, las Tareas y Calificaciones

hr.p: Nuestros profesores continuarn proveyendo oportunidades de retroalimentacin acerca del trabajo del estudiante en aquellas reas de especial contenido y destrezas importantes que necesitan aprender. Incluyendo retroalimentacin formativa canalizada a que el estudiante mejore y en aquellas reas que indican el desenvolvimiento del estudiante (grados y calificaciones). El aprendizaje del estudiante y demostraciones de su aprendizaje en la educacin a distancia o de manera remota pueden verse diferente que en persona, y requieren la flexibilidad por parte de los profesores y estudiantes.

Como recordatorio, la gua del Departamento de Educacin del Estado de Illinois indica que los grados de los estudiantes antes de entrar y en transicin a un medio de aprendizaje remoto (antes del 3/13/2020), slo pueden mantenerse o mejorarse si se involucra y habilita al estudiante de manera continua para transicionar al perodo de aprendizaje remoto. De acuerdo a los lineamiento de dicha gua, el Distrito 205 quiere compartir los siguientes detalles para dar claridad y concientizar a la comunidad escolar:

p.strong: Para los Padres de Educacin Temprana hasta el Quinto Grado (EC-5):

li.p: Se les ha pedido a los estudiantes de entre los grados de EC al 5 enviar una prueba o evidencia de su trabajo en Lectura y Escritura, y una prueba de su trabajo en Matemticas, ya sea por correo electrnico a su profesor, o por la Aplicacin SeeSaw (Por favor use la tabla contenida en la siguiente conexin para su referencia Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu. .
Si no puede mandar pruebas de su trabajo en casa, le recomendamos a los padres de familia contactar directamente al profesor de sus hijos o al gerente del caso escolar de su estudiante.

Los profesores continuarn dando su retroalimentacin cuando sea apropiada, de manera similar a los das en los salones de clase, no cada trabajo presentado al profesor ser usado para las calificaciones finales, parte del trabajo es formar y ensear al estudiante y parte es usado para informacin de conforme al estudiante y oriente al profesor del nivel del estudiante.

Los profesores estn trabajando en identificar por lo menos una tarea importante a la semana para las clases en las reas de Ingls, Lengua y Literatura, y una para el area de Matematicas, las mismas sern usadas para brindar calificaciones en el trimestre.

Todas las actividades para las clases adicionales de enriquecimiento (Arte, Msica, Deporte, Medios de Comunicacin y Espaol) en los grados de Knder a 5 se les brindar la oportunidad opcional de completarse con extensin de tiempo. Estas oportunidades de extensin sern actualizadas cada semana por los profesores como manera de proveer involucramiento y enriquecimiento. Los estudiantes pueden mandar pruebas de su aprendizaje a los diferentes profesores de estas materias especiales de enriquecimiento. Si los profesores dan una retroalimentacin ser con la intencin y la opcin de dar una extensin y servir como una opcin de enriquecimiento.

p.strong: Para los Padres de Estudiantes de Sexto a Doceavo (6 - 12):

li.p: Los equipos de profesores estn trabajando para identificar aquellas tareas importantes que sern calificadas cada semana. Para aquellos cursos que no necesitan hacer diario, como Ciencias Sociales o Ciencias Naturales, los equipos de profesores estn identificando por lo menos una tarea que sea calificada cada dos semanas.
Se proveern boletas o cartas con calificaciones a los estudiantes entre los grados 6 y 8 al final del segundo semestre.

Las siguientes materias en los cursos del 6 al 8 grados, tendrn una extensin de tiempo opcional para ser completados. Estas oportunidades de extensin de tiempo sern actualizadas diariamente por los profesores para proveer oportunidades de involucramiento y enriquecimientos. Los estudiantes pueden mandar pruebas de su aprendizaje al profesor si necesitan una retroalimentacin, sin embargo, estas materias estn consideradas como de enriquecimiento para los estudiantes.

ul.li: Banda, Orquesta, Coro, Idiomas, Msica, Arte, Educacin Fsica y Deportes, Salud, Tecnologa Creativa, Industrial, Ciencias del Consumidor y el Proyecto de Enriquecimiento: Muestra el Camino o conocido como Project Lead the Way.

p.strong: Cmo se Calcularn los Grados para los Estudiantes de 6 - 12

li.p: Los profesores continuarn ofreciendo retroalimentacin cuando sea apropiado. De manera similar a los salones de clase, no todas las pruebas o evidencias entregadas por los estudiantes sern usadas para calificar, algunas son usadas para brindar informacin formativa entre estudiantes y maestros.
Se usar una nueva abreviacin de calificacin, C1, la misma refleja el grado anterior al sistema abierto de educacin a distancia o de manera remota. (Antes del 3/13/2020).
Para la mayora de los cursos, tareas y calificaciones aadidos despus del 3/13/2020, durante la etapa de educacin a distancia o remota del segundo semestre en el que estamos, se usar S2.
Los estudiantes y los padres de familia vern diferentes cdigos entre C1 y S2 en el portal de PowerSchool para ayudar a los estudiante y las familias a entender en qu nivel estn.

ul.li: Los estudiantes NO PUEDEN bajar sus calificaciones como resultado del aprendizaje remoto, as que al final del semestre, los profesores asignarn ya sea, C1 o S2 como calificacin, dependiendo cul sea mayor.

li.p: Para clarificar, por favor tome nota que el grado del segundo semestre es temporal y puede fluctuar, subir y bajar durante este perodo de aprendizaje remoto, como lo muestra la grfica ms adelante.

Asimismo, los grados asignados no pueden perjudicar al promedio general del estudiante que tena hasta el 13 de marzo del 2020. Los grados otorgados slo pueden mejorar el promedio general como se ilustra en el siguiente ejemplo, donde el promedio general de un estudiante era del 88% alcanzado hasta el 13 de marzo y eventualmente, 91% (al final del segundo semestre como segundo promedio general).

hr.p: Si algn padre de familia o tutor tiene alguna pregunta, por favor no dude en acercarse a nuestros profesores que son muy diligentes y dedicados. Mientras nos estamos adaptando acadmicamente hablando, me gustara una vez ms, expresar mi agradecimiento a toda la comunidad escolar por su apoyo incondicional entre familias y por el continuo enfoque a la salud y al bienestar en conjunto.
Sinceramente,

Dr. David Moyer
Rector Escolar
Unidad Escolar y Comunitaria en Elmhurst, Distrito 205

div.p: April 17, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

A link to a video version of this message is available here. This afternoon, Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker issued a statement in which he suspended in-person learning for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. div.p: April 15, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

Thank you for your feedback shared through the recent District 205 Remote E-Learning Surveys. Our goal is to improve the delivery of instruction and the learning process as students engage with their peers and teachers from home due to Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzkers Stay at Home Order, which closed school campuses and facilities statewide through April 30, 2020. We appreciate your understanding as we remain responsive and flexible to implement real-time enhancements during this pathbreaking time in education amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

ISBE State Superintendent Dr. Carmen Ayala declared Remote Learning Days for schools beginning March 30 until school resumes. During this dispensation, districts are allowed to use up to five Remote Planning Days in partnership with their collective bargaining units. The days count toward the minimum length of the academic year and do not need to be made up. Last evening, the Board authorized the use of five Remote Professional Learning Days in D205.

These days will be scheduled on Fridays from April 17 through May 15 as long as schools are closed. This shift is designed to allow teachers adequate time to work with their colleagues and individually prepare more meaningful learning plans. The initial focus will be on improving consistency of implementation and developing strategies to interact more effectively with students and families. In turn, remote professional learning days also will allow parents greater flexibility to support their childs learning by using Friday as a day of study in order to complete assignments or projects from the week.

Students will not be required to log-in for attendance or submit any learning evidence on remote professional learning days. However, these planning days may be used to conduct IEP meetings when scheduled. You should continue with your learning plan for the week until you receive updated information from your childs teachers.

The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted each D205 family and staff member to varying degrees. As the days out of school accumulate, the impact on our school community only stands to grow. Each day, we must balance the basic and essential needs of health, safety and wellness with the fervor to advance learning. We believe this decision will better support meaningful learning experiences for our children, tempered with a compassion for the challenges that our families are facing.
Thank you for your input as our leadership team and teachers continue to be responsive to your concerns and evolve in this new environment.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

Dear D205 Families,

Please find a link to today's videohere. Hello!I appreciate all of you who took the time to respond to the D205 Remote Learning Survey. Your feedback is important to us. As our teachers learn and grow in this new environment, we will strive to improve our ability to support our families and foster meaningful learning experiences for our children.

Yesterday, I met with our administrative team and stressed that the Districts priority is to ensure that our families and employees are healthy and safe. I emphasized that again in a letter to our staff. I am cognizant of the fact that every day that the school closure continues, families face increasing challenges balancing personal, job and educational expectations, and that many of our families are dealing with hardship and loss. We are here to support you.

I also have reiterated to teachers the importance of adhering to the time parameters that students are expected to engage from home. In addition, my team and I are working to strengthen our ability to assess and provide feedback for students without obsessing, and having students and parents obsess,over the idea of grades.To me, this adds unnecessary stress and anxiety to a situation that is already stressful for our families.

It is a holiday weekend for many of us.For those of you who are celebrating, I hope you enjoy your family and spiritual renewal.I cannot stress enough the importance of adhering to social distancing guidelines even as you move through this specialweekend.
Again, we will adapt to the future learning challenges over the summer and into next school year. The immediate goal is to take care of each other. Please continue to stay well.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

div.p: Date: April 2, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

On behalf of Elmhurst Community Unit District 205, I hope the past few weeks have allowed your families and students to remain healthy and home together as much as possible in these challenging times.
The purpose of this communication is to provide important updates related to our evolving plans for remote e-learning procedures, including:

li.p: Plan for Continuity of Instruction
Improvements in Grades EC-5
Improvements in Grades 6-12
Instructional Tool Enhancements & Important Parent Considerations
Grading and Assessment Procedures
Student Engagement & Recommended Length of Sustained Attention

div.p: As we progress, future notices and updates will be made available through the Find it Fast menus on each schools website.

p.strong: 1. Plan for Continuity of Instruction
p.br: Yesterday, D205 staff members reviewed a comprehensive plan designed to continue academic activities while mitigating the effects of disruptions caused by COVID-19. The plan included expanded guidelines regarding roles and responsibilities for staff including special education and related service providers, assessment and grading guidelines for all levels, supports and strategies for staff, and digital tools for staff. This plan advances our curriculum and learning as much as possible while maintaining support for our students during these unprecedented times.

p.strong: 2. Improvements in Grades EC-5 (Starting Monday, April 6)
p.br: Starting Monday, April 6, students in grades EC-5 will no longer use the pre-plannedE-Learning Menu Modulefrom 3/30 - 4/3. Instead, teachers will provide a more personalized approach for each week of learning through aRemote E-Learning Weekly Menu(Sample Template).

li.p: Grade-level teams of teachers on a weekly basis at each school to create, adapt, and remotely deliver lessons in the areas of literacy, math, and specials (art, music, PE, and Spanish for applicable grades). For students participating in early childhood programming, a similar developmentally-appropriate menuherewill be developed each week.

For the week of April 6 - April 10, parents will receive their childs Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu by Sunday evening (April 5). For subsequent weeks of instruction, parents can expect to receive the Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu from their childs teacher by 5:00pm each Friday to review in advance of the next week of remote e-learning.

Parents can also expect continued communication and support from teachers, including new opportunities for student-to-teacher connections as highlighted in the section below on Remote E-Learning Instructional Tool Enhancements.

p.br: Remote E-Learning procedures for Grades 6-12 will continue as currently designed with teachers posting assignments by 9:00 am each day utilizing Google Classroom.

li.p: Students in grades 6-12 will be receiving an electronic survey to gather feedback regarding the remote e-learning experience so far. The student input will be used to make future adjustments to district procedures.

For students previously identified for intervention and additional support in ELA and/or math, parents can expect more frequent communication from teacher(s), as well as one-on-one and/or small group instruction opportunities via district-approved communication technologies.

p.br: The following adjustments to instructional tools have been made to enhance remote learning while maintaining protection and privacy for our students.

p.strong: Elementary (K-5)

td.p: Enabled for email withinelmhurst205.org and to/from teachers only.
K-5 students are not able to communicate via email externally and are not able to email each other.
Enabled for video conferencing on a session that has been established by a teacher only.
K-5 students are not able to start Google Meet sessions.
For Grades 2-12+: GoGuardian Teacher is enabled on student Chromebooks and Chrome browsers at home.

GoGuardian Teacher is a classroom management tool that allows teachers to look over a students shoulder to supervise and support, schedule classroom sessions, interact with students, push web pages, block web pages, monitor student learning activities, etc.

p.strong: Middle School (6-8)

td.p: Enabled for email withinelmhurst205.org.
6-8 students are not able to communicate via email externally but they are able to email each other directly.
Enabled but restricted to sessions that have been established by a teacher.
6-8 students are not able to start Google Meet sessions.

p.strong: High School (9-12)

td.p: Google Gmail and Google Meet are enabled for students to interact internally and externally without the restrictions that are in place for K-8.

div.p: As a reminder, technical support will be available from school and District 205 technology staff by emailingELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org. This email is operational on designated E-Learning Days only and actively monitored between 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. When an email is submitted, a work ticket will be created and assigned to the appropriate staff member. Parents and students should contact teachers or case managers for curricular or instructional questions.

p.br: The virtual classroom is like the regular classroom. Other members of a students household may be present during and even participate in the classroom environment, just like they might at school. Any person who participates in the virtual classroom, including your student, will be held to the same standards of behavior that would apply inside a classroom in the school building. If you have questions about what these expectations are, contact a building administrator for more information.

div.p: Please remember that during classroom instruction, audio and video recordings and photography are not allowed without specific permission from an administrator or the teacher. The same applies to our remote learning instruction. Do not make audio or video recordings of remote learning instruction or take photographs of your child during instruction, which include any staff member or other students without express permission from the staff member delivering the instruction or an administrator. If you receive such recordings or photographs from a source other than the District, delete them and do not post or forward. We appreciate your cooperation.

p.b: 5. Remote E-Learning Grading and Assessment Procedures
p.br: District 205s approach to feedback, assessment of student work, and grading is aligned to guidance provided by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) and designed to focus attention on key standards, ensure maintenance of existing knowledge and skills, and extend that knowledge and skill as much as possible in a remote environment. To that end, students and families should expect that teachers will provide feedback on student work in key content and skill areas, including formative feedback aimed at improvement and feedback that indicates a students level of performance (grades or scores). Student learning and demonstrations of learning in a remote setting may look different than in-person work, and will require flexibility on the part of teachers and students.

div.p: Guidance from ISBE indicates that student grades prior to the transition to remote learning can only be maintained or improved, provided the student demonstrates continued engagement and ability at a passing level after the transition to instructional remote learning day. In accordance with this guidance, D205 will assign final term grades based on a comparison of a students grade as of March 13, 2020 and the grade obtained at the end of the term including remote e-learning assignments. The higher of the two grades will be assigned as final. Note that during remote e-learning, students may be able to redo or make up some assignments from prior to 3/13/20, in collaboration with teachers, in order to improve their grades.

Students who do not engage in remote e-learning (e.g. not completing key, necessary assignments) may receive a grade of incomplete after multiple documented attempts by teachers and administrators to reach out to the students and families. Every effort will be made to work with students and families to provide opportunities for engagement that take into account individual or unique circumstances. More specific information by grade level follows:

p.strong: Early Childhood

td.p: For trimester 3, students and parents will receive report cards with information for the following measures: LLD 9 Letter & Word Knowledge; LLD 10 Emergent Writing; and, COG 3 Number Sense and Quantity. All others will be labeled unable to rate (UR).

p.strong: Elementary (K-5)

td.p: For trimester 3, students and parents will receive report cards with standards-based scores in a subset of standards in math and English language arts (ELA). For math, the standards will be based on where school teams are in the math curriculum. For ELA, 3-5 focus standards per grade for remote e-learning will be determined by the district. Using information from key assignments in those areas, teachers will assign final trimester 3 standards grades on the subsets of standards. Grades from trimester 2 will be assigned for those standards if higher than grades in those standards received in trimester 3. Process standard scores will not be assigned. Specials courses (art, music, Spanish) will be graded as pass/incomplete.

p.strong: Middle School (6-8)

td.p: For semester 2 final grades, teachers will review student grades as of 3/13/20, compare to the end-of-semester grade that incorporates remote e-learning assignments, and choose the higher grade. A specific grading term in the gradebook that ends as of 3/13/20 will be set up for this purpose. Students with a grade of F or more than one standards-based score of 1 in a course at the end of the semester (who did not have a higher grade as of 3/13), may earn a grade of incomplete. This grade will remain incomplete in a students final record unless additional arrangements are made with the students teacher prior to the end of the year and any remaining work submitted in accordance with a plan agreed upon by the teacher (and student and parent/guardian). Elective and exploratory wheel courses such as art not already completed by 3/13 will be graded as pass/incomplete.

p.strong: High School (9-12)

td.p: For semester 2 final grades, teachers will review student grades as of 3/13/20, compare to the end-of-semester grade that incorporates remote e-learning assignments, and choose the higher grade. A specific grading term in the gradebook that ends as of 3/13/20 will be set up for this purpose. Students with a grade of F in a course at the end of the semester (who did not have a higher grade as of 3/13), may earn a grade of incomplete. This grade will remain incomplete in a students final record unless additional arrangements are made with the students teacher prior to the end of the year and any remaining work submitted in accordance with a plan agreed upon by the teacher (and student and parent/guardian). If the student does not make up the incomplete, the student will be assigned no grade (NG) and will not earn credit for the course. Seniors must have successfully completed all of the credits required for graduation (i.e. with at least a grade of pass) in order to graduate.

p.b: 6. Student Engagement & Recommended Length of Sustained Attention
p.br: These District 205 guidelines for maintaining student engagement during remote learning were developed following guidance provided by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) on March 27, 2020. The thresholds in the table below are inclusive of activity, reflection, and collection or completion of learning evidence. This may also include project time that spans multiple days, independent work, and direct teacher engagement.

td.p: Early Childhood
3-5 minutes
Kindergarten
3-5 minutes
5-10 minutes
10-15 minutes
Class: 15 minutes/day Total: 90 minutes/day
Class: 30 minutes/day Total: 180 minutes/day
1 subject area or class
Class: 20 minutes/day Total: 120 minutes/day
Class: 45 minutes/day Total: 270 minutes/day
1 subject area or class

div.p: Further, teachers may be providing periodic additional optional work, engagement opportunities, and enrichment opportunities - all of which will not negatively impact a students grade.

By incorporating and adapting guidance provided by the Illinois State Board of Education, District 205 continues to improve and support remote learning procedures that meet local needs and, to the greatest extent possible, minimizes the negative impact this unprecedented moment has on our students educational futures.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

div.p: Dear D205 Families,

On behalf of Elmhurst Community Unit District 205, it is my hope that the past few weeks have allowed our families and students to remain healthy and home together as much as possible in these challenging times.

As a reminder, beginning Monday, March 30, Elmhurst Community Unit District 205 will take part in its first Remote Learning/E-Learning Week. Remote Learning/E-Learning Days are designed to serve as official attendance days of school when the students and teachers stay at home due to emergency situations, yet learning continues as students remotely leverage digital tools and engage in teacher-prepared lessons.

In order to successfully support parents in the launch of E-learning as a new process for our District, and to meet the education-related requirements provided by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE), the following information is shared for awareness and included in the Find It Fast section of the District 205 website.
Each parent and student is requested to please review the followingE-Learning Plan Overviewand to plan for completing any necessary steps in preparation for March 30th.

p.strong: What can parents expect from the E-learning process?
p.br: An E-Learning Day is not intended to mimic an actual school day in its schedule and design, but rather advance the curriculum and learning to the fullest extent possible while away from school. During an E-Learning Day, students will provide evidence of their learning experiences in various ways based on their grade level.

li.p: Staff members will be working throughout the hours of the standard school day, which includes dedicated time from 10:00 a.m. - 11:30 a.m. to be online daily to answer student (and/or, parent) questions about assignments by email, GoogleHangout, or other District-approved communication platforms.

In addition, the E-learning experience is intended to provide the necessary flexibility for both students and staff, who are also working from home under unique circumstances during this health crisis. Thank you in advance for exhibiting patience when seeking responses and feedback from staff regarding student learning.

Given the evolving challenges and changes resulting from the COVID-19 coronavirus situation, the District 205 E-Learning Plan may adjust to meet shifts at the state level, and to maintain the continuity of instruction for students by adapting instructional strategies. More information will be shared with parents in advance of any adjustments to the e-learning process.

p.br: Attendance:Between 8-11 a.m. parents must complete theDaily E-Learning Attendance Check-In for Parents EC-5. If a parent is unable to check-in a student, the student will be marked as an Unexcused Absence.

li.p: Similar to a typical school day, if a student is ill or unable to participate in the E-Learning Day, parents and guardians must call theschool attendance lineby 11:00am to report an absence from e-learning.

div.p: Assignments: For the week of March 30 - April 3, EC-5 students and parents will be able to access e-learning assignments for five (5) initial E-Learning Days and materials by clicking theE-Learning Module Menu for Grades EC-5link also located in the Find It Fast sections of each school website and the District 205 homepagewww.elmhurst205.org.

li.p: After completing all four subject areas, students should send one (1) piece of evidence total per day of e-learning from any of the four (4) subject areas (not all) directly to their teacher - either by email, SeeSaw, or when returning to school.
NOTE: Resources pertaining to any additional days of e-learning will be updated and located in the Find It Fast website sections for students and families to access.

p.strong: How does an E-Learning Day work for a student in 6th to 12th grade?
p.br: Attendance:Between 9-11 a.m. students in grades 6 to 12 must use their district-issued Chromebook, home computer, or mobile device to log into Google Classroom athttps://classroom.google.comand follow the directions in theDaily E-Learning Attendance Directions for Students 6-12to submit their attendance. If a student is unable to mark themselves present by 11 a.m., the student will be marked as an Unexcused Absence.

li.p: Similar to a typical school day, if a student is ill or unable to participate in the E-Learning Day, parents and guardians must call theschool attendance lineby 11:00am to report an absence from e-learning.
Assignments: 6-12 students will access e-learning assignments and materials by accessing the corresponding Google Classroom for each class. Teachers will post assignments by 9:00am each day.

p.strong: What if a student needs assistance with assignments?
p.br: Teachers will be working throughout the hours of the school day with dedicated time from 10:00 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. to be online and available for student (or parent) questions about assignments, e-learning, etc. Thank you in advance for exhibiting patience when seeking responses and feedback from staff regarding student learning. Technology Support is also available (below).

p.strong: How will teachers process grades during an E-Learning Day?
p.br: While grading practices and procedures may adjust with regulations from the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE), the most current guidance issued by ISBE states that Student work completed during the mandated statewide school closure must not negatively impact a students grades or otherwise impact a students academic standing. As we do not yet know the full extent of the closure and want to minimize any negative effects on students, schools may allow student work to count during the closure only to increase a students academic standing. Teachers will be receiving procedural guidance on the process for entering work completed remotely by students, and updates will be shared with parents in this process, should changes take place.

p.strong: If needed, how can students and parents receive Technology Support?
p.br: Technical support will be available from school and District 205 technology staff by emailing ELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org. This email is operational on designated E-Learning Days only and actively monitored between 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. When an email is submitted, a work ticket will be created and assigned to the appropriate staff member.

p.strong: What if a student requires assistance for a disability that may be medical or other?
p.br: For students that are eligible for related services, and whose services are missed due to school closure, staff will first attempt to make up those minutes when the student returns to the school. If those minutes are unable to be made up, the educational team will be in contact with families regarding the consideration of a compensatory service plan.

p.strong: What if a student does not have Internet access on the E-Learning Day?
p.br: District 205 has limited numbers of district-issued Wi-Fi hotspots available for family checkout; these are available by contacting the school principal. p.strong: E-Learning Update

div.p: On March 30-April 3, 2020, Elmhurst Community Unit District 205 will take part in its first Home Learning/E-Learning Week. There are no assignments for students to complete in advance during the closure period (March 16-20) and spring break (March 23-27). Looking ahead to March 30, daily attendance at e-learning will be required and recorded for our local tracking purposes. Parents of EC-5 students must have a PowerSchool SSO account by the first home learning/e-learning day in order to submit their students attendance. Our 6-12 students will use their Chromebooks to login their daily attendance through Google Classroom. Parents and students are invited to practice the attendance procedure during the spring break week (March 23-27) before we begin e-learning on March 30. This practice opportunity is optional, but recommended. Click here for details.
Our teachers and District 205 Leadership Team have worked very hard to ensure that learning can resume after the break. Please see an overview of the D205 Home Learning/E-Learning Plan here.

In the event that additional days of home learning/e-learning are needed, plans also are in development in the event that school is not able to resume on April 6. We will follow state guidelines regarding Act of God days and school closures related to grades and other considerations. Specific information will be communicated when we have clear guidelines as to what those are.

If you have questions about the D205 Home Learning/E-Learning Plan, I urge you to use the D205 e-learning inbox for technology questions at ELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org. Curricular questions should be shared by email with your childs teacher(s).
I also want to take this opportunity to clarify some things about e-learning, as I know many of you have questions.

Four years ago, the State of Illinois identified several districts from across the state to participate in a year-long e-learning pilot. The learning from those pilots formed the basis of the laws that were passed and corresponding rules and regulations adopted by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) the following year.

These e-learning days were intended to substitute for emergency days (such as snow days), so that days would not need to be added to the calendar at the end of the year due to school cancellations. They were not intended to replace traditional classroom instruction in the same way other blended or distance learning models do.

The laws and requirements initially included an extensive and cumbersome approval process. The District convened a technology committee last year with the charge of establishing a plan for future years that would coincide with the construction projects, updates of aging technology, plans for curriculum development based on the International Society for Technology in Education standards and digital citizenship considerations. Any plans also would involve an intense focus on professional learning to support D205s investment in a 1:1 learning environment, known by many as MLI (Mobile Learning Implementation).

The committee was instructed to develop e-learning plans for the District, but with everything else on its plate, it did not elevate e-learning to a top priority. Heading into last week, only 12 of 42 DuPage County school districts had approved e-learning plans on file with the State. This is one of the reasons why Governor Pritzker shut down schools effective March 17. The closures allowed many districts the opportunity to develop plans for the extended cancellation.

Last week, ISBE suspended its requirements for e-learning approval, at least on a temporary basis, and a team of District instructional coaches, technology staff, and administration did an amazing job, in cooperation with our District teachers, in developing five days worth of e-learning plans.

Despite the great work of our committed educators, due to the governors decree and some considerations related to students who do not have access to technology at home, students with disabilities and the time needed to plan for the possibility of extended e-learning in the District, the District was not able to immediately implement E-Learning Days during this first week that school is not in session.

As always, I thank you for your patience and continued support during this often inexplicable time. My central focus remains to help students, parents and staff stay healthy and safe as well as seeing students engaged in a learning process on March 30 and beyond that is robust and continues to prepare them to be life-ready.

Hace cuatro aos, el Estado de Illinois identific varios Distritos de todo el Estado para participar en un aprendizaje electrnico piloto de un ao de duracin. Dear D205 School Community,

The COVID-19 health landscape continues to evolve rapidly as evidenced by Governor Pritzkers mandate that all schools close across the state. The governors decision was in sync with my decision on Friday in advance of that announcement to close all Elmhurst Community School Unit District 205 schools and offices beginning Monday, March 16, 2020. div.p: D205 also will offer Grab-N-Go Meal Service to students during the closure period at Churchville Middle School and York High School on the following schedule.

My leadership team and I will continue to keep the school community informed as any new information, clarifications and updates become available. I thank you for your patience and attention in advance as there likely will be numerous pieces of communication in the coming days. Please take time to read the messages that come your way.

Although this decision was a difficult one, students, staff, and parents alike were understandably growing in concern and worry with every conversation and media report as cases in surrounding counties were confirmed. Even yesterday as the governor announced the first confirmed case in DuPage County, it is now clear that the strategy in our school community must shift from business as usual to the preventive measure of social distancing.

D205 is operating with guidance from the DuPage County Regional Office of Education and the experts at the DuPage County Health Department. They continue to explain to us the CDC guidelines for COVID-19, and how they work to keep us safe. Our government and health officials have advised that social distancing is the most proactive approach to this health crisis. Therefore, we have put into place personal protective measures to close down our schools for students and non-essential staff as our buildings are extensively cleaned and disinfected.

In order for this strategy to be effective and minimize anxiety, I ask that you take seriously the following actions based on recommendations by the CDC and the DuPage County Health Department even if you feel healthy and are not considered at higher risk because of age or a pre-existing health condition:

li.p: Avoid gathering in public places, especially in close proximity to others.
Avoid close contact with those who are sick.
Try to keep 6-10 feet between yourself and others. Give yourself space.
Be at home as much as possible.
Try to limit who you and your children interact with to the same people you typically are around.

p.strong: Students and families should not:

li.p: Gather in large groups. This is a time to be close with those who are closest to you.
Visit each others homes or having sleepovers.
Share food or drink.
Compete in team sporting activities. Use this time to train individually or with someone in the home.

p.strong: Students and families should:

li.p: Avoid excessive media coverage of COVID-19.
Be mindful. Take deep breaths, stretch or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, and get plenty of sleep.
Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy to return to your normal life.
Spend time outside. Grabbing some fresh air and exercise are two of the best things you can do over the next few weeks.
Share your concerns and how you are feeling with friends or family members. Maintain healthy relationships.
Use technology and social media for good purposes. Support one another and show that you care.
Maintain a sense of hope and positive thinking.
Keep following the practice of washing your hands regularly and covering your cough or sneeze.

div.p: I also am asking families to evaluate non-essential travel during the coming D205 Spring Break. D205 is following the guidelines and recommendations set forth in the CDCs Travel Advisory. There are requirements to self-quarantine post travel to Level 3 destinations contained in the advisory link above (scroll to the bottom of the page) and guidelines to limit interactions post cruise travel. Domestic travelers also are asked to evaluate plans if traveling to an area where COVID-19 is spreading. Be mindful that conditions can change between the travel period and the return home.

If you still plan to travel internationally during the break, I am asking families to complete D205s voluntary self-reporting form. This request again is voluntary but is being made out of an abundance of caution. We want to have all the available information on hand to share with health officials to help District 205 leaders make the most informed decisions.

The D205 leadership team will follow up with a lot more information related to support services as well as teaching and learning plans. Student well-being and learning are the top priorities during this unprecedented time.

Again, I understand that the coming weeks will be challenging, but I ask that the school community come together to flatten the curve and help stop the wide spread of illness. Lets be the example for our children by exhibiting the most healthy and safe practices possible.
Most importantly, please take care and stay well. I will be in touch again soon.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit District 205

div.p: February 28, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

Since the Center for Disease Controls announcement on Tuesday, parents in our school community and across the nation are seeking information regarding health and education plans should the impact of the coronavirus spread as predicted. We understand and share in the anxiety that an announcement of this magnitude produces. The health, safetyand well-being of our students and staff is our first concernevery day. We will continue to update you as new information for our county and school district develops. As with any global health issue, the situation evolves rapidly and recommendations are subject to change.

District 205 has maintained regular communication with District 205 Health Services, DuPage County Health Department and the Illinois Department of Public Health as they process the latest guidance from the CDC. According toIDPH, the risk to Illinoisans still remains low.

We also are engaged in conversations with the Regional Office and Illinois State Department of Education and awaiting further guidance should an extended closure of school be required. There are currently no recommendations to cancel classes or activities.

District 205 Health Services is monitoring symptoms of illness and attendance. Masks and gloves are not currently recommended by IDPH at this time. Please contact the school nurse if you would like to discuss your childs health history or a health-related absence. When calling or leaving a message, please provide as much detailed information about the nature of the illness as possible.

Also, D205 Facilities and Grounds teams will continue with daily and nightly cleaning practices, including disinfecting surfaces, door knobs, restrooms and water fountains. High traffic areas like front offices and nurses stations will receive extra attention as well.

Finally, while the coronavirus news is very concerning, it is important to point out that respiratory viruses like the flu are still circulating. Fever, coughing and difficulty breathing are symptoms associated with all of them. Therefore, anyone exhibiting symptoms should not be assumed to have COVID-19, but should seek appropriate medical attention.
The following preventative measures or non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs), also can help avoid getting and spreading respiratory illnesses:

li.p: Your child should stay home if sick until at least 24 hours after there is no longer a fever or signs of a fever (without the use of fever-reducing medications).
Covering coughs and sneezes with a tissue. Wash your hands following the use of a tissue.
Washing hands with soap and water or using hand sanitizer when soap and water is not available.
Staying home if you have been exposed to a family or household member who is sick.
Covering your nose and mouth with a mask if you are sick and around people or at a mass gathering in a community where the pandemic is already occurring.
Please consult your healthcare provider if you have a concern for yourself or a family member shows symptoms of illness.
Consultadvisorieswhen preparing to travel outside of the country, particularly to already impacted areas.

div.p: Thank you for your time and attention to this important matter. Again, we will provide updates as more information becomes available.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205
